bug.short_desc: [search] Java search result view should not enable polymorphic filter by default

long_desc.thetext:
3.3 M2 warm-up build.
Talking with philippe about polymorphic methods functionality added since bug 73401 has been fixed, it seems that setting Search View default to filter polymorphic matches is not a good idea.
The consequence of this default is that user may not have all matches while searching for method references (ie. change is breaking current behavior) and so can think it's a bug in Search Engine. As we also need to finalize this functionality on some missed specific cases (sub-types, generic methods, final classes, etc.), it's better not to change current behavior.
Functionality will still be there, but not documented and without impact on current behavior.
Martin, OK to revert for M2? (BTW: The original bug for the 'polymorphic' bit was bug 73401).
The idea is that polymorphic should go away in its current form, and allow to distinguish between referenced from subtypes vs. supertype/sibling (through interfaces).
See also bug 157814 for ongoing discussions.
Created an attachment (id=50548) Trivial fix
Fixed for 3.3 M2.

the polymorphic filter is still available, but not checked anymore by default
verified in 20060922-0010

bug.short_desc: Issues with ShapeCompartmentEditPart.ConnectionRefreshMgr

long_desc.thetext:
There are a few issues with the ShapeCompartmentEditPart.ConnectionRefreshMgr.
1. Currently, the connection anchors are used to find where the end of the connections are to see if they should be visible or hidden. ConnectionAnchor sc = cep.getSourceConnectionAnchor(); ConnectionAnchor tc = cep.getTargetConnectionAnchor(); However, the connection anchors don't reflect where the start/end of the connection is if the user added bendpoints. This could lead to the situation where the connection is shown between cylinder1 and cylinder2 in the attached screenshot. I tried to fix this by using the points in the polyline to figure out the start/end location, but these will not be updated in the connection is currently being hidden.
2. There is a method isBorderItem() that can be overridden. If I override that in the LogicShapeCompartment to return true for TerminalEditParts (clients are doing something similar) then if I scroll so that the two LEDs are out of the shape compartment the wire will always be shown because it is between two border items. See the attached screenshot.
Created an attachment (id=50461) screenshot of issues

The ConnectionRefreshManager in ShapeCompartmentEditPart determined whether a connection should be visible or not based on the location of the source and target and the connection anchors being used. If there were bendpoints, these were not taken into account. I changed the ConnectionRefreshManager to take into account the bendpoints.

bug.short_desc: [search] polymorphic matches in supertype hierarchy should be marked as potential

long_desc.thetext: I would distinguish a.m() as a polymorphic match (or whatever you call it), whereas b.m() and c.m() are equivalent since they target the exact same method (statically).

You could demonstrate the same with introducing a B2, which could in turn override #m().
c2.m() would be considered polymorphic to me, where c.m() not, since unless overriden, it is invoking the exact same method (which is the same as any other reference to a B variable, which could in turn invoke a B2#m()).
Along these line, I suspect interface methods need to be considered differently, since you would miss all interesting subtype scenarii.

(In reply to comment #0) > > As discussed in bug 73401 comment 17, I think that subclass matches are of > "higher quality" than superclass matches, I think we all agree on this point. > and that superclass matches should therefore be flagged as potential. > But not on this one. Potential matches are reserved when Search Engine is definitely unable to say that a match with correct name and qualification is valid or not. This flag is typically set when there's no binding; unknown reference or external reference in a class file.
IMO, a possible approach would be to consider different flags in all cases we want to distinguish (and need brain storming for names)...
Currently, I see 3+1 different cases for referenced method: 1) call to super type method: a.m() 2) call to type method but from a sub-type: c.m() 3) call to a sub-type method which overrides the searched method: c2.m() 4) 1)+3) (if I add "class D2 extends C2 {}" and "d2.m();" to the test case)???
BTW, I still do not know why this is interesting to distinguish the sub-types methods from exact matches? From bug 73401 and bug 156491 only case 1) is annoying, we didn't any complain about 2), 3) and of course 4) ones...

(In reply to comment #4) > Potential matches are reserved when Search Engine is > definitely unable to say that a match with correct name and qualification is > valid or not.
Ok, I misinterpreted the 'potential' flag, then. I do not require that specific flag, all I wanted is a way to distinguish the two cases.
> BTW, I still do not know why this is interesting to distinguish the sub-types > methods from exact matches?
I am all for only flagging super-type polymorphic matches. Rationale: IMO the use cases for this flag (certainly bug 73401) focus on the possible runtime type X of the receiver r of a method call, and whether X is assignment compatible to the type Y declaring the method we are searching for.
In the sub-type case, this is certain, while in the super-type case, this may or may not be true. Hence, the super-type case can produce false-positives, possibly many.

I agree with Tom, the flag seems to be necessary only for super types. But, in addition, I would say that we need to distinguish specific test case for interface (comment 5).
I also think we need to find another name for this flag which sounds now not really appropriate as polymorphic methods may be both on super-types and sub-types... I have no precise idea about it but something like SUPER_TYPE_METHOD and POTENTIAL_INTERFACE_METHOD (if we distinguish interface test cases...).
Markus, I definitely need your point of view on this before finalizing the implementation.
As this functionality is already in 3.3 M2, I think we need to finalize it to have correct behavior in an integration build as soon as possible => increase priority to P2

I agree that case 1) of comment 4 is the only interesting case if we don't consider interfaces. Proposed flag for case 1): /** * Returns whether the reference is on a method that is overridden by the * search target or not. If true, the method called at run-time * may or may not be the search target, depending on the run-time type * of the receiver object. * * @return true if the reference is on a method that is * overridden by the search target, false otherwise */ public boolean isOverridden() Since we don't have any requests for the potential interface matches (references to methods with same signature in interfaces that are not supertypes or subtypes of the target method), I think it would be best to remove them again and just have the isOverridden() property for now. People that are interested in potential references to the interface method can always search for references to that method instead.

Created an attachment (id=51564) Proposed patch
Replace isPolymorphic with isOverridden, thanks Markus for the well documented API proposal :-)

Created an attachment (id=51565) Proposed patch for JDT/UI
To test this I've also create a patch for JDT/UI... Hope this help :-)

Released for 3.3 M3 in HEAD stream.
Note that I've put back MethodReferenceMatch.isPolymorphic() method otherwise nightly build will have compilation error. I've set as deprecated and will remove it only when JDT/UI will remove all references to it...
No specific test case added, existing ones already shows the change of behavior...

Released improvement for API name + additional test in JavaSearchBugsTest Common agreement was done on following API for MethodReferenceMatch: /** * Returns whether the reference is on a message sent from a type * which is a super type of the searched method declaring type. * If true, the method called at run-time may or may not be * the search target, depending on the run-time type of the receiver object. * * @return true if the reference is on a message sent from * a super-type of the searched method declaring class, false otherwise */ public boolean isSuperInvocation()
Verified for 3.3 M3 using warm-up build I20061030-0010

bug.short_desc: TaglibIndex in WTP 1.5.1 logs exceptions when Java based projects are closed or deleted

long_desc.thetext:
I believe the fix related to 87143 added this side effect to TaglibIndex in WTP 1.5.1. This change has not yet been applied to WTP 2.0 which is not showing this behavior.
In the handleClasspathChange(IJavaProject project) method, the "IResource resource = project.getCorrespondingResource();" line is now being reached for projects being closed or deleted. This call will perform and "exists()" call on the IJavaProject which throws the "Java Model Exception: Java Model Status [JavaProject does not exist]" that appears in the Error Log.
It wouldn't hurt to avoid this "noise". Someone looking at the Error Log and seeing these occurring in the past might wonder if something bad had been happening.
Created an attachment (id=50464) Patch to avoid "processing" projects being deleted or closed
*** Bug 158585 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 159405 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Nitin, I'd like to fix this in 152, if we fix anything else in jsp core, since it really does interfere with ready those JUnit logs. But, if not fixing anything else in that plugin, not sure it's worth it then, but, I'd like your advice. It seems a very safe fix for a problem that is not so bad, but which will be reported a lot by users since it sure looks bad. Thanks for considering.

Created an attachment (id=51392) updated patch
Attaching a modified patch (thanks for the original, Larry). When a Java project is closed or deleted, the associated the description object should also go away (if deleted, it's useless, if closed, it's potentially stale if re-opened later). Otherwise it's just as before.
Requesting PMC review for 1.5.2. It really is confusing noise for end-users and it's clogging up our own BVT logs (to say nothing of adopters').

+1 Thanks Nitin (and Larry). Looks good to me, and normally "messages in the logs" wouldn't be "stop ship", but these do clog up our JUnit logs, which are clogged enough already with other spurious messages. (Those others don't show up in normal use, but this one sure does).

+1
project is closed, therefore should not be a logged as an error
Not clear how this is a 'critical' fix ("It wouldn't hurt to avoid this "noise".) The fix appears safe, but aren't we opening the door for other such issues to get into 1.5.2?
FYI: I forgot to try renaming a java based project. This also triggers this exception.
A quick follow up: I've confirmed that the change commited to WTP 2.0 fixes the problem for project delete, close, and rename.

(In reply to comment #9) > Not clear how this is a 'critical' fix ("It wouldn't hurt to avoid this > "noise".) > The fix appears safe, but aren't we opening the door for other such issues to > get into 1.5.2? >
Thanks Raghu. Its a valid concern, but I think we can all use care to not allow it to "open the door". Each bug should be evaluated on its own merits. It is true I would probably not support this if we not also "touching" the jsp.core plugin (to fix other things). But one reason its important to me is we've beeen getting lots of "time outs" in our JUnit testing lately, making it hard to get a good build. And while I do not know all of the reasons for that time out (might be some other server we are dependent on, or something) but as I've studied the logs to try and figure it out, this is one of the notable differences of current logs and previous logs ... so, it would make me rest easier to be able to rule it out as an explaination for the time-outs.
Released for 200610050200.
+1 for WTP 1.5.2
Verified M-1.5.2-200610121759 build doesn't log the exception for close, delete, and rename of Java projects and Dynamic Web Projects.
closing. (thanks everyone)

bug.short_desc: [jobs] Allow jobs to specify RW locks for scheduling

long_desc.thetext:
Jobs allow you to set a scheduling rule on them to allow scheduling. In some cases, you don't need/want to use a scheduling rule.
For example: I have an index that is not stored in the workspace (its in the metadata folder.) I've come up with a Reader Writer lock solution that allows multiple readers, but only one writer. Since there is no good way to map reader/writer locks into SchedulingRules, I am forced to aquire RW Locks within the job. This basically ties up the job in it's execute method - which means its occupying a worker thread that could be used by other Jobs. If there is a lot of access to the index, this could easily create 20-30 threads.
I'm requesting allowing an alternate way to hook into the job scheduling mechanism. So that the job should not be executed while the writer lock is active.
Maybe there can be a way to hook the Job manager implementation with the Java 1.5 concurrent libraries.

I don't see why you can't implement read/write lock semantics by implementing your own scheduling rules. A WriteRule would conflict with any instance of ReadRule, and ReadRule would conflict with WriteRule but not with other ReadRule instances.

I think if you were using WriteRule/ReadRule like you mention, it works fine in isolation and if you are using jobs. However - and this is deviating a little from the original request - you couldn't implement a general Reader/Writer lock using scheduling rules alone. That is what if you need to block on a Read from the index from within a workspace modify operation (with workspace root rule). You can't just do a JobManager.beginRule(ReadRule) because the WorspaceRoot rule doesn't "contain" the ReadRule. I thought I could maybe do this using job.join(), but in some cases that failed too. (I.e. during workbench restore, the jobmanager is suspended, and join() returns immediately)

bug.short_desc: not possible to mark a folder as landmark or to just induce interest when temporarily unfiltering

long_desc.thetext: Folders, as well as some other resources like I think Java files as opposed to Java classes can't be made a landmark using the mark as landmark action. It is on the other hand possible to mark as less interesting. A folder can have interest so I cannot see a reason why it can't be a landmark. In the same category is that if I do temporary unfiltering using Alt+click, I can't select a folder and induce interest. A workaround at the moment would be to select a file in the folder which makes both the file and the folder visible. And then make the file less interesting, so that I end up with the folder having interest.

There are two issues here: if you would like folders to gain interest via Alt+Click, please put that comment on bug 112233. I agree.
Regarding folders being landmarks, this decisions was made because they are not structured elements in the same way as Java methods or classes are (some discussion is on bug 118007 and bug 111165). However, for files that Mylar does not have a structure bridge for we removed the restriction and allow files to be landmarks. We could consider doing the same for folders and other kinds of containers. However, note that this is challenging because one thing that I know looks horrible is to see both bold folder and a bunch of bold files in that folder, since it adds too much visual noise.

I agree with your reasoning that not both a folder and its contents should be landmarks. However in that case I think that the action item should not be available and greyed out. I don't know whether that would be compute intensive but if a simple condition exists: don't show "Mark as Landmark" if the selected item is e.g. a Java class. Added new bug 199655

bug.short_desc: Can JUnitWorkbenchShortcut be made public API

long_desc.thetext:
We are currently using org.eclipse.pde.internal.ui.launcher.JUnitWorkbenchShortcut to run a JUnit Plugin test using its launch(ISelection selection, String mode) method. The passed-in selection is an org.eclipse.jdt.core.IType.
Can this functionality be made public?
In addition, it would be very helpful if the implementation supports launching with the "minimal" application. Currently, the launch is done with the UI/IDE application. This is overkill when headless mode will do. Could the implementation have some smartness to pick the minimal application by analyzing the plug-in pre-reqs?
See also bug 157818.

This was already done for 3.3 M2 (coming out this week) as part of a bigger launch API sweep.
It is now org.eclipse.pde.ui.launcher.JUnitWorkbenchLaunchShortcut.

As for: >This is overkill when headless mode will do
The shortcut is already smart.
We recursively look at the list of dependencies of your selection. if swt is encountered along the way, we launch the IDE app. Otherwise, we run headless.
That's what allows jdt/core to launch headless via a shortcut.
Therefore, you must have swt somewhere in the dependency chain of your selection.
If you are sure that you don't, reopen and we will examine.

bug.short_desc: Feature-based model migration patches should NOT use object identity equals() on metamodel

long_desc.thetext:
A migration rule assigned to a meta-model feature is checked against features processed during model load. Currently, such a binding is realized by using identity based equality (myFeature == feature).
MigrationConfig class binds migration rules to feature instances from the generated package class. It is not guaranteed that the same instances will be used during model load.
A [packageURI + eClassName + eFeatureName] key should be used instead for rule-feature match.
Committed.

bug.short_desc: [ICU] com.ibm.icu.math.BigDecimal.toBigDecimal() missing in com.ibm.icu

long_desc.thetext:
I'm getting the following runtime error when running code in Eclipse 3.2 that was compiled against a standard distribution of ICU4J 3.4.4 (from IBM's FTP server)
java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: com.ibm.icu.math.BigDecimal.toBigDecimal()Ljava/math/BigDecimal;
Sure enough, decompiling the com.ibm.icu.math.BigDecimal class in eclipse\plugins\com.ibm.icu_3.4.4.1.jar shows the API isn't there.
This is very strange as - the above API has existed in official ICU distributions for a long time (definately since 3.4) - ICU4J 3.4.4 and 3.4.5 contain this API. - the version number of this plugin indicates that it is v3.4.4.1 - the source code distributed in eclipse\plugins\com.ibm.icu.source_3.4.4.1\src\com.ibm.icu_3.4.4.1\src.zip does contain a class method implementation for this API.
Note, I'm marking this as a critical issue as due to https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=145988 we don't have any choice but to use the version of ICU4J shipped with eclipse (especially when the bundle declares itself to be the version we want!)
So it seems that the binary jar does not match the declared (or any other) publically available version of ICU, at least in respect to this API - I can't say if any others differ.
Note I can't find a 3.4.4.1 distribution on ftp://ftp.software.ibm.com/software/globalization/icu/icu4j/ but I don't think that matters much as both 3.4.4 and 3.4.5 do support this API.
This method was disabled due to the requirement that ICU4J in Eclipse needs to support 1.0 Foundation execution environment.

(In reply to comment #1) > This method was disabled due to the requirement that ICU4J in Eclipse needs to > support 1.0 Foundation execution environment. >
Wow, I didn't see that coming! Looking at the source again, I can see the //#ifndef FOUNDATION comments (euuugghh!)
Is this a fair thing to do? You are distributing a plugin that is exporting packages containing classes that do not comply to their published API. You are breaking JDK1.3 bundles in order to facilitate CDC-1.0 bundles.
How about creating two ICU bundles, each containing different 'editions' of ICU and each specifying their appropriate runtime environment in the OSGi manifest. Would Equinox load (only) the correct version for the host runtime?
e.g something like
com.ibm.icu.cdc10_3.4.4.1.jar#META-INF/MANIFEST.MF containing
Bundle-RequiredExecutionEnvironment: CDC-1.0/Foundation-1.0
and
com.ibm.icu.jdk13_3.4.4.1.jar#META-INF/MANIFEST.MF containing
Bundle-RequiredExecutionEnvironment: J2SE-1.3

I have an interim workaround for this - package our own com.capeclear.icu plugin that exports packages specifying a higher version number -
Export-Package: com.ibm.icu.impl;version="3.4.5", com.ibm.icu.impl.data;version="3.4.5", com.ibm.icu.lang;version="3.4.5", com.ibm.icu.math;version="3.4.5", com.ibm.icu.text;version="3.4.5", com.ibm.icu.util;version="3.4.5"
and then I changed the dependent bundles to specify this version number in their Import-Packages:
Import-Package: com.ibm.icu.impl;version="3.4.5", com.ibm.icu.impl.data;version="3.4.5", com.ibm.icu.lang;version="3.4.5", com.ibm.icu.math;version="3.4.5", com.ibm.icu.text;version="3.4.5", com.ibm.icu.util;version="3.4.5"
However, I fear that you will break this workaround when you update ICU in your distribution to 3.4.5 (https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=157680).
Please consider the suggestion to package two ICU bundles, one for each target runtime environment (assuming Equinox will correctly load the appropriate one at runtime).

Someone on the equinox team will have to comment on the runtime logistics of your suggestion.
Note that ICU4J 3.4.5 has already been released into Eclipse 3.2.1 and will be released into 3.3 after M2 is declared. So 3.4.5 might not be a good verison name for your workaround.
If the package versioning bug (bug 145988) were resolved would this bug become less critical for you?

One possibility could be to have a patch fragment that is only needed when running on foundation. This fragment would only have one class (com.ibm.icu.math.BigDecimal) without the toBigDecimal method. This class would override the one in the original icu bundle (which does have the toBigDecimal method).
To do this you would have to open up the Bundle-ClassPath in the icu bundle to accept the patch fragment. For example,
Bundle-ClassPath: patchForFoundation.jar, .
CC'ing Pascal and DJ to see if they have other ideas.

From my understanding of the problem, Tom's suggestion would work but only for the case where the methods/classes in question do not expose any of the non-foundation classes as API and where the javadoc allows us to return null.
So we would like to stub out some classes/methods like the above-mentioned #toBigDecimal. But can we do that? I think the only way to do that is to return null for the method but since that method is not spec'd to return null, then we would break callers and it wouldn't conform to the API.
This is also a problem if any of the problem classes are subclasses, extend an interface, or expose a non-foundation class in a method signature or field.

Part of what DJ describes is the issue today but in reverse. Today we have a class that is completely missing the toBigDecimal method. So if there is code out there that compiled against the "real" ICU library then it will get runtime errors when run against the eclipse version of ICU.
I suggested the patch fragment for foundation for the following reasons:
1) Other bundles running and compiling on foundation will never using the BigDecimal method because they will not be able to really use the methods return value.
2) The patch fragment just removes the method in the same way that the method was removed from the original ICU library jar. So any concerns about removing the method here should not be worse than the original removal.
There actually is a reason this may be cause problems. The foundation patch fragment would not be delivered with the SDK by default (I would suggest it is an optional download that can be used if needed on a foundation VM). This means the toBigDecimal() method will be available at development time for a bundle that compiles against the foundation class library. Some experimentation would need to be done to make sure this does not cause any unexpected errors.
What about my suggestion to ship two bundles, each specifying different values for their Bundle-RequiredExecutionEnvironment header?
Tom, what if there is a case where an entire class was removed to meet the F1.0 requirement? Can I remove an entire class using the fragment solution?

JohnO, to answer your question, that solution sounds like a maintenance nightmare (double the number of plugins = double the amount of work). And I doubt the ICU team would want to maintain such a solution. It would be much cleaner to be able to deliver one ICU4J bundle and an optional fragment to accommodate a different minimum EE. There is also the possibility that the replacement plugin (com.ibm.icu.base) would also have to provide a parallel fragment to mirror the API in the real ICU4J plug-in's fragment (if we go with this solution) to match the API provided by the real ICU4J plug-in. This would complicate the already odd process of using the replacement plug-in.
No, fragments cannot remove complete classes. The best you can do in a patch fragment is to provide an empty class that overrides the one from the host
Is it possible to do the opposite of what you suggested and have the fragment add the classes/methods that were removed for the F1.0 requirement, instead of removing them?

yes, but this would require the fragment to be included in the SDK. Something I thought we were trying to avoid. The fragment would still need to be a "patch" fragment so that it can replace any classes in the host which it needs to add methods for.
If we decided to do this then you could use the existing icu bundle in eclipse as-is except you would have to add a patch-fragment classpath entry to its Bundle-ClassPath manifest header. For example,
Bundle-ClassPath: jse_fragment.jar, .
This allows a patch fragment to be installed which contains the jar jse_fragment.jar that has the classes you want to override from the host. Notice that jse_fragment.jar appears before '.' in the Bundle-ClassPath. This is important to allow us to load classes from it before classes in the host.

I guess it depends on which solution is more desireable. Why do we have to ship the patch fragment with the SDK if we ship the host bundle as the smaller subset of function (as it currently is)? Were you thinking that fewer people probably have the F1.0 restriction on them so why not give the SDK the larger set of function as a default, in the hopes that fewer people will require the extra download (of the fragment)? I was thinking the opposite - that the platform only wants users to take a particular subset of function and the rest is gravy, which they can get by downloading the separate patch fragment. Does any of this sound off base?

Yeah, that makes more sense to me now that I think about it. For thoughs that want the complete API they would have to install the extra fragment. Then the current host bundle would be able to be used on all the different execution environments as is (except the additional patch fragment classpath).
Ok, I think we will give this strategy a try and see how it goes.

Created an attachment (id=54025) test plugin and fragment
Help! I am having trouble with the fragment strategy. It appears that the class in my fragment is not being found, despite having the fragment jar on the classpath of the plugin.
My plugin has a class that with 2 methods - methodA and methodC. The fragment has the same package/class with 3 methods - methodA, methodB, methodC. When I create a new plugin project, pre-req the plugin bundle, and then create a test class that attempts to use methodB, the method is not found - the other 2 methods are found, of course.
Can any of the osgi gurus listening to this bug take a look at my test plugin and fragment to see what might be wrong? I have tried this with both Eclipse 3.2 and 3.3 M3 so I figure I must be doing something wrong. I believe this strategy should work since the workbench.compatibility fragment appears to do something similar.
Don't we need "Eclipse-ExtensibleAPI: true" in com.ibm.icu plug-in to allow the fragment to extend APIs?

Pascal or Oleg should be able to help you out here. This is identical to the patch fragment to the org.eclipse.equinox.registry bundle. The host bundle needs the following header to tell PDE to place fragment content on the classpath of any bundle that depends on the host.
Eclipse-ExtensibleAPI: true
The fragment needs the the following header to tell PDE to place the library from the fragment before the content of the host when the host is added to a classpath
Eclipse-PatchFragment: true
Both of these headers have absolutely no meaning at runtime. They are only needed at tooling time to correctly construct the classpath for compilation.
Also see bug 163384 for PDE improvements WRT patch fragments.

Using the headers specified in Tom's comment works for my sample plugin and fragment (thanks for the tip, Tom).
However, using the ICU4J plugin and fragment there are runtime errors since. The purpose of the fragment is to replace a class with the same qualified name by changing something - method signatures, superclasses, etc. A class in the plugin may have a different superclass then the class with the same (qualified) name in the fragment - the LRUMap class is an example of this.
Similarly, method signatures are changed i.e. the type of a parameter in the plugin is changed in the fragment due to the EE restriction on the plugin. ICUResourceBundle is an example - it has a method #getBinary() that returns an ICU ByteBuffer in the plugin and a java.nio.ByteBuffer in the fragment. This is problematic at runtime because the bytes were compiled against the code in the plugin, but is run against the code in the fragment, so NoSuchMethod errors are encountered.

In light of the runtime errors that happen when attempting to run current version the fragment (which supplied JDK 1.4 compatible implementations for both internal and API methods and classes) we will slightly re-define the content and use of the fragment. 1. Yoshito will identify APIs missing from the ICU4J bundle and provide the JDK1.4 compatible implementation of these. 2. Users of ICU4J in Eclipse must know that the ICU4J bundle + fragment in Eclipse will be functionally, but not binary, equivalent to ICU4J that on the ICU website. Obviously, this is already the case for the ICU4J bundle that is in 3.2 (com.ibm.icu).
Yoshito, you should open a separate bug against PDE-UI

(In reply to comment #23) > Yoshito, you should open a separate bug against PDE-UI
I filed this bug against PDE a while ago -> https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=181644

bug.short_desc: Connecting data through two different databases

long_desc.thetext:
Sorry for the question but this is a major problem at our side. I need to write a single data retrieval query to generate the report. That query is accessing data from the tables of two different databases. Those two databases dont have any kind of data link between them and a data link also cannot be created. The constraint on my side is that I need to bring the tables of different databases in a single select query only. I cannot create two different data sources and corresponding data sets to retrieve the data.
Is there any way to create a data set which can connect to two different data sources to write a single query on it?
Thank you

Just forgot to mention one thing that I can use only BIRT 2.0.1 due to deployment problems on Weblogic 8.1 SP5. That is to say that I cannot use the Join Data Set feature which is there in the new BIRT 2.1.
Thank you

One way to solve this issue is to write java script to access both the data bases.You can create data access classes using java language, then package it to a jar file and put it into "scriptlib" directory under viewer.However by using this way you will have to implement data join yourself and that would be not easy.
As you have mentioned that there are deploy problems using BIRT 2.1 in your environment. Can you file a bug for this?As far as I concern if that bug is fixed this "joint data" problem will be fixed automatically.
Thanks. Lin

My query is pretty complex. I have to create left join, sort on 4 variables, substitute null values and much more to be done. I can try doing all those things manually in the code but the there is no guarantee that the output generated will be the exact as needed. So I am skeptical to gor for that option.

bug.short_desc: [Examples] Alt-F malfunction when Examples plugin installed

long_desc.thetext:
After installing the Examples plugin, the Alt-F no longer causes the File menu to be displayed.
The Examples plugin provides a Field Assist Example. When the examples are installed, the Field Assist Example installs a main menu item using Alt-F as the hotkey. This places two items on the menu w/ Alt-F shortcut, File and Field Assist.
As a result, Alt-F does not drop the File menu, it only highlights the menu. The user must use the down-arrow to display the menu.
The Examples should be modified to use some other hotkey for the Field Assist Example.
marking for M3
verified in I20061031-0656, WinXP.

bug.short_desc: READ_ONLY Combo shows list before pop-up menu

long_desc.thetext: Using Control example. Set combo to be READ_ONLY and turn on the popup menu. Right click the combo. First the list is displayed, once it is dismissed the popup menu is displayed.
Changing OS from Mac OS to Mac OS X as per bug 185991

bug.short_desc: [CheatSheet] Cheat sheets menu item.. where did it go?

long_desc.thetext:
Eclipse has moved this menu item to the SDK (org.eclipse.sdk) in 3.2. Our Product is based on the Eclipse runtime and does not include all of the Eclipse source, and thus we do not get the menu item.
We need to understand why has the Help > Cheat Sheet... menu item has moved and how can it now be accessed?

> We need to understand why has the Help > Cheat Sheet... menu item has moved and > how can it now be accessed?
If you just copy/paste the actionset definition in to your plugin from the SDK plugin.xml (and the attendant properties in plugin.properties) you can get the menu item back. but really the actionset definition should be in one of the cheatsheet plugins, probably org.eclipse.ui.cheatsheets.
It's funny, I was just about to submit this exact bug, but you beat me to it by a few hours.
Thanks for the workaround Crispin. We had to do that for our product as well. What we are not able to explain is why it was moved, and thus this defect was borned.

This problem is being tracked in bug 120087. Please see that one for the history. I'm still not sure what will come out of it.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 120087 ***

bug.short_desc: [CommonNavigator] Project Explorer Does Not Support Java Drag and Drop

long_desc.thetext:
Just in case this hasn't been reported yet, I can't drag and drop Java files or packages onto the Project Explorer. I need to switch to the Java perspective.
Aslo, for other resources, I just use the Resource perspective now. The Project Explorer should support full drag and drop like the other views.
Both the resource and java content support drag in drop in the latest WTP 1.5.1 from the project explorer. Also, these contributions are at the eclipse platform level and not at the WTP level.
John, I tried dnd on wtp-sdk-M-1.5.1-200609150551.zip and it failed. I tried to drag a package into the Java src.

To recreate the error open Windows Explorer and find a directory that contains a Java class suitable nested as per its package structure. Drag the root directory for the package onto the src node of the Project Explorer - you get a "not allowed" mouse pointer. Now try this in the Java perspective. It works correctly there.

Arthur, can you confirm of DND works within the viewer? That is, can you drag a Java element onto another location within the Project Explorer? Is this issue specifically with DND events that originate outside of the workbench?
Michael, I can DND from one project to another. But not from Windows Explorer into a project.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 156333 ***

bug.short_desc: Decorations disappear in Tree when adding Columns

long_desc.thetext: Decorations don't appear to be added to trees when a tree has columns. My decorations appeared on the tree. I added a column, they disappeared. I removed the column and Eclipse started adding them again.
Can you attach a screen shot of a stand alone snippet that shows the problem?

Sorry, I worked on this bug for several days and it seemed to be an eclipse problem. As soon as I reported the bug, I found it in my code. Please remove.
- Kurt Klinzing. Non-Bug reporter

bug.short_desc: [Workbench] enable progress reporting on startup if branding properties are set

long_desc.thetext:
Currently, you have to enable progress reporting on startup by setting the preference org.eclipse.ui/SHOW_PROGRESS_ON_STARTUP to true. (Default is false)
We should report progress on startup if preference has its default value but there are values for the properties controlling where the progress message should appear.
Not fixing this means that people who use the product editor will have a hard time tracking down why their startup progress reporting is not showing.

bug.short_desc: [Edit] Compare with Each Other should use file buffers

long_desc.thetext: The equals in the ResourceNode is flawed in the sense that it uses the resource name for equality. Unfortunately, there are parts of Compare with Each ther that rely on this (see bug 157654). We should fix the equals and the Compare with Each Other action.
Verified in HEAD
Is this now for M2 or M3 as advertised in bug 157654 comment 7?

I think Bogdan closed this thinking it was bug 157654 was was fixed for M2. However, the proper fix has not been done (i.e. ResourceNode now has a flawed equals method and Compare with Each Other depends on this).

After some reflection, I've decided not to change the existing class because it is possible that existing clients rely on the flawed behavior. I've changed the title to indicate that we shoudl investigate whether file buffers should be used with Comapre with Each Other. However, we do not plan on addressing this in 3.3.
We are reworking Compare with Each Other in 3.4 at which point, we should be able to move back onto File Buffers.
*** Bug 181178 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

bug.short_desc: Print out the source codes that have insufficient commenting

long_desc.thetext:
Use the CLOC program (http://cloc.sourceforge.net/) to determine the number of lines of comments relative to number of lines of source code. Create a script to determine source files that have insufficient commenting. Convert the result of CLOC to HTML and post it on the download page for every driver. Use a rule of thumb for the amount of comments that should be in a source file (e.g. at least 1 line of comment for every 20 lines of source code).
The developers should then be requested to properly comment their code. This should significantly improve the maintainability of TPTP code.
Use the following arguments with CLOC: cloc --exclude_lang="HTML,XML,Bourne Shell,DOS Batch,Make" --by_file <plugin_location>
Created an attachment (id=50477) Sample output of CLOC
We could generate the requested reports but without sufficient funding to do the identified clean up, this request has no resulting value.

bug.short_desc: Delete the configuration folder on export

long_desc.thetext: When exporting an rcp app multiple times in the same folder and running it in between exports, users are being faced with problems where the configuration is out-of-date and the app is run from the cached state and registry leading to weird behaviours. In those cases, it would be good if PDE could surgically delete the content of cache in the config area.

bug.short_desc: ATF bundles package org.eclipse.swt.browser in plugin org.eclipse.atf.mozilla.swt.browser

long_desc.thetext:
Short:
In trying to run ATF on Linux 64bit I've never managed to get it going. I found some time today to debug the problem and think I found it.
The plugin org.eclipse.atf.mozilla.swt.browser ships with all the compiled class in the the package org.eclipse.swt.browser.
However the Platform base SWT bundle for Linux ships org.eclipse.swt.gtk.linux.x86_64_3.2.1.v3235.jar which also contains one or more classes in the package org.eclipse.swt.browser.
I think that the ATF plugin org.eclipse.atf.mozilla.swt.browser is volating general namespace rules and think that all the code should be refactored and exported in the package org.eclipse.atf.mozilla.swt.browser.
Long:
$ jar -tvf /opt/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.swt.gtk.linux.x86_64_3.2.1.v3235.jar | grep "browser/[MNO]" 248 Tue Sep 12 17:58:26 BST 2006 org/eclipse/swt/browser/OpenWindowListener.class
This demonstrate the class org/eclipse/swt/browser/MozillaCloseWindowListener is not shipped with the Eclipse base Platform bundled SWT.
However the ATF project attempts to provide it here:
$ jar -tvf ~dlm/.eclipseextension/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.atf.mozilla.swt.browser_1.0.1/mozilla_swt.jar 0 Tue Sep 12 13:33:44 BST 2006 META-INF/ 106 Tue Sep 12 13:33:42 BST 2006 META-INF/MANIFEST.MF 0 Tue Sep 12 13:33:42 BST 2006 org/ 0 Tue Sep 12 13:33:42 BST 2006 org/eclipse/ 0 Tue Sep 12 13:33:42 BST 2006 org/eclipse/swt/ 0 Tue Sep 12 13:33:42 BST 2006 org/eclipse/swt/browser/ 1284 Tue Sep 12 13:33:42 BST 2006 org/eclipse/swt/browser/AbstractMozillaBrowser$1.class 716 Tue Sep 12 13:33:42 BST 2006 org/eclipse/swt/browser/AbstractMozillaBrowser$2.class 716 Tue Sep 12 13:33:42 BST 2006 org/eclipse/swt/browser/AbstractMozillaBrowser$3.class 27603 Tue Sep 12 13:33:42 BST 2006 org/eclipse/swt/browser/AbstractMozillaBrowser.class 3703 Tue Sep 12 13:33:42 BST 2006 org/eclipse/swt/browser/EmbeddingSiteWindow.class 1788 Tue Sep 12 13:33:42 BST 2006 org/eclipse/swt/browser/MozillaBrowser.class 272 Tue Sep 12 13:33:42 BST 2006 org/eclipse/swt/browser/MozillaCloseWindowListener.class 1223 Tue Sep 12 13:33:42 BST 2006 org/eclipse/swt/browser/MozillaDownload$1.class 8318 Tue Sep 12 13:33:42 BST 2006 org/eclipse/swt/browser/MozillaDownload.class 1046 Tue Sep 12 13:33:42 BST 2006 org/eclipse/swt/browser/MozillaDownloadFactory.class 2264 Tue Sep 12 13:33:42 BST 2006 org/eclipse/swt/browser/MozillaHelperAppLauncherDialog.class 1136 Tue Sep 12 13:33:42 BST 2006 org/eclipse/swt/browser/MozillaHelperAppLauncherDialogFactory.class 269 Tue Sep 12 13:33:42 BST 2006 org/eclipse/swt/browser/MozillaOpenWindowListener.class 1387 Tue Sep 12 13:33:42 BST 2006 org/eclipse/swt/browser/MozillaPromptDialog$1.class 1605 Tue Sep 12 13:33:42 BST 2006 org/eclipse/swt/browser/MozillaPromptDialog$2.class 1759 Tue Sep 12 13:33:42 BST 2006 org/eclipse/swt/browser/MozillaPromptDialog$3.class 6019 Tue Sep 12 13:33:42 BST 2006 org/eclipse/swt/browser/MozillaPromptDialog.class 6773 Tue Sep 12 13:33:42 BST 2006 org/eclipse/swt/browser/MozillaPromptService.class 1076 Tue Sep 12 13:33:42 BST 2006 org/eclipse/swt/browser/MozillaPromptServiceFactory.class 679 Tue Sep 12 13:33:42 BST 2006 org/eclipse/swt/browser/MozillaVisibilityWindowAdapter.class 296 Tue Sep 12 13:33:42 BST 2006 org/eclipse/swt/browser/MozillaVisibilityWindowListener.class 1420 Tue Sep 12 13:33:42 BST 2006 org/eclipse/swt/browser/MozillaWindowCreator$1.class 923 Tue Sep 12 13:33:42 BST 2006 org/eclipse/swt/browser/MozillaWindowCreator$2.class 3758 Tue Sep 12 13:33:42 BST 2006 org/eclipse/swt/browser/MozillaWindowCreator.class 744 Tue Sep 12 13:33:42 BST 2006 org/eclipse/swt/browser/MozillaWindowEvent.class
It seems that BOTH a component of ATF and a component of Eclipse base Platform SWT use the same package name org.eclipse.swt.browser. The Java class loader *does not* perform an exhaustive search for all memebers of a package, once it find the first JAR file (or classes/ directory) that matches it consider that the only authoritative location for all the classes that make up that package.
I am thinking that the package name is a typo in the CVS file:
eclipse_cvs/atf/components/plugins/org.eclipse.atf.mozilla.swt.browser/META-INF/MANIFEST.MF Export-Package: org.eclipse.swt.browser
I think it should read:
Export-Package: org.eclipse.atf.mozilla.swt.browser
Then everything within ATF that uses it need to be refactored.
Maybe Win32 version of SWT does not ship with the package org.eclipse.swt.browser and this is why developers have not been aware of this problem before. But marking this as critical as ATF has never worked for me and I would like is anyone has ATF running on any version 32bit/64bit of linux and if so that other plugins do they have installed ?

I have found some OSGi options to enable with "-debug $HOME/.options" to give a more verbose output of the class finding process (the following information I have extracted in the order they appear that I think it relevant and related to this problem) :

I must have tried over 120 combinations of plugins trying to recreate the problem and find a pattern. 25% were 32bit based, 75% were 64bit based. I tried doing Update Manager driven updates for TPTP, Birt and other items which I have installed to look for any contributing effects and found none. I have upgraded base platform and WTP to recent development I-build and again ATF work with 32bit.
In not one case was I able recreate the OSGi error message problem, about org.eclipse.swt.browser Require-Build being invalid. The 32bit setups worked out of the box. None of the 64bit setups worked at all (When I say they dont work, this always means In the Mozilla perspective, I press the open URL button, put in a url and get a Mozilla tab drawn, but the contents are transparent, i.e. no redraw is done inside the tab and none of the browser widgets appear).
So my conclusion is that there is a corruption in the configuration data that was causing org.eclipse.atf.mozilla.swt.browser to be rejected by OSGi and not able to get into "RESOLVED" state.
So I went back to trying to find a reason why 64bit doesn't work.
I have checked into all sorts of other possibilities, like the fact that my Linux 64bit uses GCC4 and this stdc++.so.6 using a different ABI to applications complied with GCC3 (stdc++.so.5). So I recompiled my xulrunner using (gcc32, g++32, which I have installed) and check everything is using/linked with GCC3 ABI. This made no difference to the problem.
I have chased down the erronous ClassNotFoundException's coming of OSGi when it tries to load classes in javaxpcom.jar. But there is a specialist ClassLoader in url and the classes are really found, as the exception must have been generated inside OSGi resolution. Maybe OSGi could be taught about this specilist classloader situationt hat ATF presents so the errors are quashed.
I then looked at the output during startup of an ATF embeded browser tab. I have found the point where the startup procedure changes between the working 32bit and the non-working 64bit. Shortly after posting the last comment I was able to get a new error in ~dlm/workspace_clean64/.metadata/.log:
!ENTRY org.eclipse.ui 4 4 2006-09-22 17:44:17.090 !MESSAGE Unhandled event loop exception
!ENTRY org.eclipse.ui 4 0 2006-09-22 17:44:17.091 !MESSAGE handle !STACK 0 java.lang.NoSuchFieldError: handle at org.eclipse.swt.browser.MozillaBrowser.getHandle(MozillaBrowser.java:16) at org.eclipse.swt.browser.AbstractMozillaBrowser.<init>(AbstractMozillaBrowser.java:232) at org.eclipse.swt.browser.MozillaBrowser.<init>(MozillaBrowser.java:12) at org.eclipse.atf.mozilla.ide.ui.browser.MozBrowserEditor.createPartControl(MozBrowserEditor.java:245) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.EditorReference.createPartHelper(EditorReference.java:596) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.EditorReference.createPart(EditorReference.java:372) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.WorkbenchPartReference.getPart(WorkbenchPartReference.java:566)
So I got to work on this and found in eclipse_cvs/atf/components/plugins/org.eclipse.atf.mozilla.swt.browser/gtk_linux_src/org/eclipse/swt/browser/MozillaBrowser.java at line 32: OS.gtk_container_add(handle, embedHandle);
accesses a field called "handle". I sound that was an inheritied field from class o.e.swt.widget.Widget, MozillaBrowser -> AbstractMozillaBrowser -> Composite -> Scrollable -> Control -> Widget (has "public int /*long*/ handle")
So I decompiled (with javap) the SWT Widget.class for the 32bit and 64bit builds of SWT and found:
32bit SWT: public abstract class org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Widget extends java.lang.Object{ public int handle; ...}
64bit SWT: public abstract class org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Widget extends java.lang.Object{ public long handle; ...}
So therefore a field lookup for a field called "handle" of int type, will throw a NoSuchFieldError on 64bit and this is the cause of the current problem.
I think I have an idea to be able to have one common build for linux/win32 on 32 and 64bit, so the ATF download page just has a single thing to download. I also think that the build server on any platform can be used to build that common distribution, so long as it has a copy of the relevent JARs for each of the platforms available in the compilation classpath.
So in the comming days I shall try to attach a patch or zip for the org.eclipse.atf.mozilla.swt.browser to rework the build process and demonstrate that it is possible to build it from any host platform for all targets (because there is no Native code in use).

I am happy to report I have got ATF working on 64bit Linux today. I think my remaining issue was related to GCC3/GCC4 ABI differences as my host builds for GCC4 by default.
To confirm what I have working:
I built my own Xulrunner 1.8.1 using CSV tag MOZILLA_1_8_BRANCH. Using the options 'CC="gcc32" CXX="g++32" make -f client.mk MOZ_CO_PROJECT=xulrunner' this results in an ABI compatible version of xulrunner using GCC3/stdc++.so.5.
I installed this weeks ATF atf-linux-sdk-0.1-20061004-2300.zip
I build my own version of plugins/org.eclipse.atf.mozilla.swt.browser_1.0.1 which uses long return type for 64bit in AbstractMozillaBrowser and MozillaBrowser classes.
Then I fired up Eclipse and I am able to browse :) So from this standpoint I'm happy to close this bug as the original goal has been achieved, that is to see ATF working on 64bit Linux.
There are followup items already being worked on to unify the download.
Now I noticed in the CSS view the error "Required Xulrunner classes not found. Full CSS tooling only supported with XULRunner version 1.8.1 or later" so I track this down to lack of org.mozilla.xpcom.inIDOMUtils class in org.mozilla.xpcom_1.8.0.4 but it is in the MozillaInterfaces.jar of 1.8.1.
So I tried to build my own version of plugins/org.mozilla.xpcom_1.8.1 out of the 1.8.0.4 version with the MANIFEST updated and the JAR replace from my 1.8.1 xulrunner build.
However now I get this error:
java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: org.mozilla.xpcom.nsIAppShell.create([J[Ljava/lang/String;)V
And looking at the java stub _javagen/default/org/mozilla/xpcom/nsIAppShell.java:
void create(int[] argc, String[] argv);
dist/idl/nsIAppShell.idl:
void Create(inout int argc, inout string argv);
Now in 1.8.0.4 the "argc" argument is of type "long" (if I decompile the .class file) which is what the "J" in "([J[Ljava/lang/String;)V". The nsIAppShell.idl file on both version uses type "int".
It looks like the "idl" to java compiler fixed to use an int type when appropiate.
When I fixed my customer build of org.eclipse.atf.mozilla.swt.browser to call with "int []" I can confirm ATF is working on 1.8.1 for 64bit Linux as well.

(In reply to comment #17) > I am happy to report I have got ATF working on 64bit Linux today.
Great. Thanks for working on this.
> I build my own version of plugins/org.eclipse.atf.mozilla.swt.browser_1.0.1 > which uses long return type for 64bit in AbstractMozillaBrowser and > MozillaBrowser classes.
I assume you only had to change the methods dealing with the SWT 'handle', correct? Could you attach a patch of the changes you made?

bug.short_desc: eJFace StructuredViewer not handling selection events correctly

long_desc.thetext:
On win32, arrow keys and single click should generate widgetSelected event. Double click or Enter should generate widgetDefaultSelected event.
On WM, arrow keys should generate widgetSelected event. Single click or Enter should generate widgetDefaultSelected event. Double click is not very usable, but should generate widgetDefaultSelected event.
On S80, arrow keys should generate widgetSelected event. Enter should generate widgetDefaultSelected event.
StructuredViewer which consumes these events to determine when to fire SelectionChanged() method call should only generate SelectionChanged on widgetDefaultSelected.

Turns out the problem was really in how eWorkbench and the e-mail app were using TableViewer. They were looking for SelectionChanged() to be called in order to open a table item. However, TableViewer has a specific open() call for this. Therefore, I changed these apps to use the right call, and changed eJFace StructuredViewer back to its original event processing.

bug.short_desc: Equinox and automated integration testing

long_desc.thetext:
This is a test bundle written for the purpose of automating the installation of bundles and (later) executing test cases within bundles. This bundle starts a thread that does:
1. Scans a directory for Jars 2. Tries to load Jar as a bundle 3. on success, checks for other version of same bundle 4. if exists, unintalls other versions 5. installs and starts new bundle 6. upon install and start success, deletes jar from directory.
The bundle "brute forces" bundle starting by continually tying to install/start bundles in the directory. In the case of a bundle failing to start due to a dependency not yet available, that bundle may get sucesfully started on another pass of the loop.
This bundle was written to support an embedded development enviroment involving development boards being used by multiple teams. Performance and integration tests need to be run without the java build system having complete control of the target environment.
Refer to this newsgroup thread for additional details:http://www.eclipse.org/newsportal/article.php?id=2088&group=eclipse.technology.equinox#2088
This bundle has yet to incorporate any automated test launching.
Created an attachment (id=50490) First draft of automated testing bundle.

attachment.desc: First draft of automated testing bundle.

bug.short_desc: moving column can lose sort indicator

long_desc.thetext:
3.3M2, gtk+ 2.4.13
- run the ControlExample and go to either the Table or Tree tab - turn on: Multiple Columns Header Visible Sort Indicator Moveable Columns Resizable Columns - this puts the sort indicator in the first column - move the first column to follow the second column, this works fine - now move this column back to become the first ordered column and note that the sort indicator has disappeared

This looks like a bug in the control example. On any platform, turn on "Header Visible" and "Sort Indicator." Click "Name" column header once, sort indicator indicates up, click column header again, sort indicator goes away, click again and it shows down.

Dragging a tree column in GTK 2.4 sends a button release event (in _gtk_tree_view_column_start_drag), triggering the clicked signal that the control demo code ultimately uses to change the sort order. So the initial drag from colum 0 to column 1 changes the sort order from DOWN to UP, then the drag back to column 0 changes it from UP to NONE.
This gtk bug is related: http://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=159037
fixed in HEAD > 20060921

bug.short_desc: [Help] Parent topic listed at bottom of User Assistance topic is repeated three times; eliminate all but one of these links

long_desc.thetext:
Repeated three times at the bottom of the User Assistance topic is the link to Product Overiew, the parent topic. Eliminate all but one of these links to Product Overview.
Related defect...
The topic, "The Workbench," is missing a parent link at its bottom.

The screenshot you have provided appears to come from an IBM product, not eclipse. Note that this is a public forum and all content must be accessible to the public. Please pursue the issue with the appropriate product team - eclipse does not add parent links to documents.
For the missing link on the workbench page, this is a valid request however we intend to tackle it in a different way for 3.3 - using bread crumbs at the top. This will allow the user to go back up any level in the table of contents tree. That enhancement hasn't been opened yet so stay tuned.

Hi Curtis,
Has an enhancement related to bread crumbs been open? Is there a place that the Eclipse committers would prefer any discussion to take place over another?
I'm asking because one implication came up recently in some colleague discussion: what would the breadcrumb trail look like if that particular topic exists in two ToC branches?
I am assuming that by "bread crumbs" is meant a trail that reflects the hierarchical relationship for that topic, and not a Hansel-and-Gretel breadcrumb trail that reflects all the points of the user's clicked-through path that they took to arrive at that topic at that moment in his or her life. General usage in the industry seems to be that "breadcrumb trail" = the hierarchical relationship and not the clicked-through path (which could be truly odd depending on what path the user was doing.)
--Lee Anne
I've opened bug 166391 to track breadcrumbs. Let's discuss there.

bug.short_desc: ScopedPreferenceStore stops firing events after removing the last listener

long_desc.thetext:
After removing the last listener from a ScopedPreferenceStore instance, that instance will no longer fire property change events if you add a new listener. This is because in removePropertyChangeListener, if the list of listeners is empty, disposePreferenceStoreListener() gets called, which removes the internal listener from the internal IEclipsePreferences, but does not set the listener list to null. The next time addPropertyChangeListener is called, it sees that the listener list is not null, so does not re-initialize it.
This could be fixed by setting the listener list to null at the end of disposePreferenceStoreListener.
Sorry, I meant it could be fixed by setting the internal preferencesListener to null at the end of disposePreferenceStoreListener, not the listener list.

If you look at disposePreferenceStoreListener you will see that the preferencesListener is cleared at the end of the method.
Do you mean doing something with getStorePreferences()?
I will add a test suite to demonstrate but this looks like it is working for me.

Nope, this looks good now. The line setting preferencesListener to null is not in the 3.1.2 codebase, and this was causing it to break. I didn't have the 3.2 code handy to check when I filed the bug. Thanks!

bug.short_desc: After some changes in model and updating the GMF mapping some of old digram files cannot be opened

I update the model to allow WidgetA to be placed on the diagram and into container widget, and I update the gmf mapping. After generation some of the old diagram files cannot be opened. I'm not sure where is the problem, maybe it's because of different VisualID Nodes.
Did you try using bridge.trace plugin functionality?
Using trace functionality makes it possible to preserve visual ids. Decreasing severity as there's way to deal with the issue. Perhaps, we should mature .trace plug-in from experimental to base sdk?

bug.short_desc: [FastViews] Placement of experiemental fast views awkward

long_desc.thetext:
I20060918-2000
Minimize a view that's to the top right of the screen so that it appears in a fast view bar on the right side of the screen. Activate the view and it appears right next to the fast view bar. Good. Drag the bar to the bottom of the screen and activate the view again. The view now appears to the far left of the screen in the traditional fast view spot. I'd expect it to appear near the bar.

Absolutely correct. Actually I'm working on makeing it work more like context menus:
Given: a size (Uses have already requested the ability to resize pane) the FVB location
Show the pane aligned with FVB location offset to be within the bounds of the workbench if necessary.
If either the width or height is > the workbench bounds then it will (temporarily) resize to fit.

The stacks now get created on the closest side and all User changes (i.e. dragging to another side) are maintained.
The only known exception is that if you have stacks in the trim in two or more perspectives only the active perspective's stacks maintain their state through a shutdown/restore cycle.
The trim position persistence issue will be covered in the new layout code...

bug.short_desc: [CommonNavigator] Confusing working set menu items when showing working sets at top level

long_desc.thetext:
I20060918-2000
If you set the Project Explorer to use working sets as top level elements the working set menu items (Select Working Set, Deselect Working Set, and Edit Working Set) become confusing. Although the standard working set dialog does appear to work it's not at all clear that you're selecting a list of working sets to show. The package explorer provides its own dialog for this purpose. If you feel that we should be providing this dialog for all clients please open a new PR against platform-UI.
What if the default dialog displayed a "Show as groups" checkbox?

I dont think that would be applicable across the board - most viewers aren't configured to show working sets as elements. That also doesn't address the additional menu items - deselect and edit are useless in this scenario.

I vote for using the dialog from the Package Explorer. The reason is that it also allows custom sorting of Working Sets which the default dialog doesn't provide.
There is also another usability issue. If you select Working Sets as top level elements the first time and no Working Sets are selected than ALL should be visible instead of an empty view. (3.3 M5) Maybe there should be a warning that no Working Sets are selected and the view will be empty.

The behavior that Gunnar refers to has been fixed (showing all when no working sets are supported, but still exists for Window working sets - bug 190819)
Martin -- what are your thoughts on contributing the Working Set dialog to Platform?

Yes, I think it would be good to have the working set selection dialog in platform as well. Platform already has a selection dialog, but it is more targeted to select a working set filter: You can choose 'Window working set' and 'No Working Set', which make no sense in our scenario. So we could think of making the existing dialog more configurable. Important is also that the selection dialog we need filters out some working sets (we only want Java and Resource working sets), and allows the artificial 'Other Projects' node. So in the end it might be easier if you reimplement the dialog as there are so many special requirements here.

bug.short_desc: ChangeDescriptionImpl doesn't have any ordering between object and resource changes

long_desc.thetext:
ChangeDescriptionImpl doesn't provide any ordering between object and resource changes. As a result when doing applyAndReverse (as part of undo), changes don't happen in a proper order.
Assuming a destroy eobject scenario in which changes are done in the following order,
1. A feature on the destroyed object is modified 2. destroyed object is removed from its resource container. 3. adapters on the destroyed object are cleared.
When undoing this using applyAndReverse the changes happen in the following order 1. feature is restored to its old value 2. destroyed object is added back to resource (as a result the content adapters get added)
it is expected that undo happens in reverse order.

There is no contract to say what order things are done in, nor can I see any way to make that happen. All that is guarenteed is that the final state is correct. The way things are recorded, we only record what's changed, not the order in which things changed. So all changes for a particular object will happen as a batch, before we process the changes for the next object. And since resource changes are recorded separately, those will happen separately. We can't "fix" something like this with the existing change description design.

The commons-logging JAR should be copied from the org.apache.commons_logging plugin (preferred) or the org.apache.axis plugin if the first is not available.

Created an attachment (id=50495) Fix that correctly located the commons-logging jar on WTP 1.0 & 1.5.
This patch makes openVXML Studio search for the commons-logging JAR in the org.apache.commons_logging plugin as well as the org.apache.axis plugin.

bug.short_desc: Very long parameters in selection drop-down for new wizards

long_desc.thetext:
I20060919-0010
I was trying to find the New Plug-in Project command in the command composer. I found File -> New but when I go to select the New Wizard parameter, I get complete descriptions of the wizards, each on a single line, as opposed to just the names.
Is there any way we can just show the name of the new wizard?
See screenshot to follow.

unable to reproduce here either.
I think it's because I installed samples while testing welcome. Try playing with samples then testing.
Janek, how do you populate the combo box? what API do you call?
Janek, see my previous question.

The combo box is populated by the names of the parameters. We call IParameter#getValues()#getParameterValues()
In turn, this returns a Map object with names as keys. We iterate through the key set Map#keySet()#iterator() and fill the combo box.
getParameterValues() has the following javadoc:
Returns a map keyed by externalized names for parameter values. These names should be human-readable, and are generally for display to the user in a user interface of some sort. The values should be actual values that will be interpreted by the handler for the command.
Returns: A map of the externalizable name of the parameter value (String) to the actual value of the parameter (String).
Janek, the problem here is that we are showing the wizard description, not the name. is it us? is it the command framework? or is it the owner of the extension point?

the screenshot is not legible. apparently, the readme editor and other samples have very long descriptions.
Moving to Platform/UI to make them short.

Alternately, we could just show the ID of the command in the combo box. I don't think we can legislate name length to people.
Moving back to PDE.
Perhaps the combo box should be populated with ID and you see the description upon hovering over it or something.

It seems to be because WizardParameterValues is using IWizardDescriptor#getDescription() instead of getLabel().
It even has the comment: // Note: using description instead of label for the name // to reduce possibilities of key collision in the map
Later, PW

Thanks Paul. Moving back to UI.
Paul, could this be addressed for M2 if possible?
Thanks.

I'll have to look at it tomorrow. I can't just use the simple change, getLabel(), since if any names are the same you would only get to select the last one added.

bug.short_desc: Support different parsers in single source-file

long_desc.thetext:
The current C/C++ parser doesn't handle language extensions such as inline assembler. It produces bogus warnings for ARM assembler.
It would be good to provide an extension point such that a plug-in parser could "take over" for a section. I suppose an alternate way of looking at this would be to demote the C and C++ parsers to one-of-many and provide an extensible source file partitioning mechanism.
Though it's tempting to use Regular Expressions for this partitioning - it should be noted they're not able to match brackets. Any ideas?

My expectations regarding this were that the inline assembler should be treated as a part of a "container" language. So in case e.g. some C language dialect supports some different inline assembler syntax, a separate ILanguage (org.eclipse.cdt.language extension) should be defined for that C language that would parse the assembler accordingly.
Doug, is this correct? If not, we might think about making some modifications to the current New Project Model design to properly support inline languages.

I think this all plugs into the language extensibility story which we really haven't taken a serious shot at. We need to take a step back and consider all the cases where languages can be mixed in a single source file and maybe the solution will become more obvious.
If it is only assembly, then maybe there's something we can do in the parser where we can detect when assembly is being used and call out to a new parser to take over for a bit and then return. Neil, can you attach examples of source files where the current parser gets confused.

bug.short_desc: [Cheat Sheet Editor] Cheat sheet editor outline problems

long_desc.thetext:
I20060919-0010
There are a few small bugs with the Outline view support with the Cheat sheet editor.
- Selecting something in the outline affects the editor, except when you select the root cheat sheet element. - Link with editor doesn't work - if you turn it on then change selection in editor, the change is not reflected in the outline view. - The sorting is actually harmful in this case because the steps follow a specific order and sorting messes up the order. Is it possible to turn it off?
I don't consider the outline view that important for making cheat sheets, so this is all minor.

Fixed for both the simple and composite cheat sheet editor.
Target: 3.3 M3 Patch: patch_157888_2006-11-01_14-14.txt Patch released to HEAD
Overview:
The root element in the outline view actually represents the cheat sheet form page and not the root cheat sheet node. I've restored the root cheat sheet node representation in the outline view tree (under the form page representation) so it is now selectable. It doesn't really make sense to represent the cheat sheet form page because there is only one page in the editor (nothing to switch between). However, for consistency I am leaving it in (at least until the form page tab is removed).
The "Link with Editor" feature doesn't work across all PDE editors. The functionality is implemented in the form editor base classes. The selection provider being used to get the proper selection seems to opearate at the form level or lower (e.g. form is selected - rather than some element in the form). As a result, selections from the master tree view are not detected and relayed over to the outline tree view. I could not find a general solution to solve the problem for all PDE editors, because depending on the page, you may want to trigger selection by different things (e.g. tabs vs. trees). I could add selection listeners to all relevent form children programatically; but, this seems wasteful; since, only a select few items are representable in the outline view. However, I was able to come up with a nice solution for the cheat sheet editors that leverages existing form editor base class methods and listeners. I will open up corresponding bugs against the other PDE editors at a later date.
I've left the sorting toggle button alone. I agree that the sorting can be counter-productive; however, someone may want it (especially if the composite cheat sheet group is of kind set or choice) and without it the outline view has zero value-add.
Work Done:
* Represent root cheat sheet nodes in the outline tree view
* Fixed "link with editor" feature -> Synchronize master tree view selection with outline tree view selection when the button is toggled on - Override base form editor class get selection method to get the proper selection -> Update selection in outline tree view with selection in master tree view properly using a post selection changed listener - Reused PDE form editor change listener in base class

bug.short_desc: Need a PDE Problems category

long_desc.thetext:
When you have a problem due to an issue with your manifest file there is no decent way to filter them to find the root problem.
Example 1) Get 3.2.1 2) Load org.eclipse.search from HEAD 3) There are 30 odd errors. The two that matter are two Unsatisifed Links which are lexically last so really hard to see

PDE markers have their own marker id. To filter for only PDE markers, in the problems view select the filter icon. On the right hand side of the Filters dialog, there is a checkbox tree with all available types. Click "Deselect All" and then check "PDE Problem". Click OK and you should see only markers coming from PDE. Hopefully this helps.
Wassim set me straight on what the bug was asking for. Sorry for the confusion. Reopening.

Brian & Wassim, what categories are you thinking of here?
So far I have (modeled after JDT): Fatal Errors Deprecation Externalized Strings
Thoughts?

The number one thing for me is the dependency errors that prevent you from doing anything else. They should be in a category on thier own (and it should be first) as all other errors are a side effect.

Created an attachment (id=51393) org.eclipse.pde.patch
Please review for sanity Brian.

we have these categories:
Fatal Errors Deprecation Execution Environment Externalized Strings
Feel free to open other requests if you would like other categories :)

In the Body text field, the last sentence shown is "Let's getstarted!". Note the lack of space between get and started. This is because in the XML source there was a line break. It appears ok in the cheat sheet view though. I think perhaps the editor should show a space here.

Work Done * No longer strip \n, \r, \t and duplicate spaces from element and attribute values on load -> Only strip leading spaces and trailing spaces -> Done to preserve cheat sheet XML file input -> e.g. Text separated by newlines preserved instead of stripped * Modified PDE label provider to strip \n, \r, \t and duplicate spaces from label values displayed in the master tree view and outline view * Significantly refactored, cleaned-up and generalized PDE text helper translate write text method -> Implemented in a performance-sensitive way -> Strips user defined set of characters on write -> Substitutes user defined map of characters on write (including brackets, quotes, ampersands) -> Preserves user defined set of HTML tags (without escaping) on write * Using new translate write text method, perform custom character stripping, character substitution and tag preservations as needed for each field type -> e.g. Preserves line formatting (newlines and carriage returns) in step body text fields -> e.g. Substitute '&' for "&" -> e.g. Preserves
and tags

bug.short_desc: [Cheat Sheet Editor] Confusion with Help section in cheat sheet editor

long_desc.thetext:
I20060919-0010
In the details part of the cheat sheet editor, there's a Help section that has two radio buttons:
(x) Specify a fully-qualified help context ID: [___________]
( ) Specify a help document link: [___________]
The problem is that radio buttons are used for a fixed number of mutually exclusive options, where you have to select exactly one of them. So here the UI says to me "You can either specify a context ID or a help doc. You can't specify nothing, you have to pick one of those two".
I don't have a clear answer, just want to document the problem. Some possibilities include:
- A third radio button (no help) - A checkbox with the radio buttons in a section (do you want and help at all?)

Patch: patch_157898_2006-09-29_16-26.txt Target: 3.3 M3
Patch released to HEAD
Work Done:
* Re-designed and Re-implemented the UI for the Help section
-> Represent the "Help Context ID", "Help Document Link", "<none>" tri-state selection using a combo box
-> Allow user input through a text field that becomes visible when "Help Context ID" or "Help Document Link" is selected in the combo box
- Focus set on selection

bug.short_desc: Missing mnemonics in cheat sheet editor

long_desc.thetext:
I20060919-0010
The cheat sheet editor has some mnemonics, like for the buttons, but not for the Definition section in the details side. Also, the Body text can actually input tabs so I cannot tab my way to the two checkboxes below it (accessibility problem).

Wassim, correct me if I am wrong, but editors should not be using mnemonics since it interfers with the main menu selection, right?
Curtis, you should be able to tab through the text body with a ctrl + tab.
So the only action that should be taken with this bug is to remove the mnemoics from the editor.

right.
Brian, please remove the current mnemonics as they are the source of confusion.
Fixed. Targeting for 3.3M2
